p: Although commercialized as Lavandula stoechas L., the presence of necrodane derivatives, such as 5-methylene-2,3,4,4-tetramethylcyclopent-2-enone (18%) in the analyzed essential oil, undoubtedly indicated that the butterfly lavender tested was L. luisieri and not L. stoechas ( Table 3). The chemical composition of L. stoechas essential oil is characterized by large variations in fenchone, camphor and 1,8â€‘cineole amounts, whereas necrodane derivatives are characteristic of L. luisieri [ 23, 24, 62]. Even though some variations in their contents were observed, the remaining essential oil compositions were in accordance with previous studies carried out with Foeniculum vulgare [ 15, 63], Mentha cervina ([ 25] and references therein), Origanum majorana [ 64], Satureja montana [ 58, 65], Thymbra capitata, Thymus mastichina, Th. pulegioides, Th. vulgaris and Th. zygis subsp. zygis [ 28, 64, 65, 66], Eucalyptus species [ 67, 68] and Pinus pinaster [ 33, 69].
